title: Effects of the fish anesthetic, clove oil (eugenol), on coral health and growth
authors: Boyer, S.E.; White, J.S.; Stier, A.C.; Osenberg, C.W.
journal: Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology

analysis.summary: Researchers studied how the timing and order of arrival affects competition between two reef fish species that settle on coral reefs at slightly different times, finding that who arrives first gets a competitive advantage.
analysis.keyQuestion: Does the sequence and timing of when competing fish species arrive on a reef affect how strongly they compete with each other?
analysis.approach: They manipulated when two wrasse species (Thalassoma hardwicke and T. quinquevittatum) were introduced to experimental patch reefs in French Polynesia, varying both which species arrived first and how much time separated their arrivals, then monitored survival and aggressive interactions.
keyFindings: Both species survived best when they had no competitors, but when competitors were present, they did best when arriving simultaneously
Survival declined as each species entered the community progressively later than its competitor
Late-arriving fish faced increased aggression from early-arriving competitors
The competitive advantage of arriving first applied both between species and within the same species
analysis.stickyFact: Fish that arrived at the same time survived best when competitors were present, but survival declined as they arrived progressively later than their competitor.
analysis.whyItMatters: This research shows that small differences in timing - just days or weeks - can determine which species dominate coral reef communities, providing evidence that competitive lotteries help maintain species diversity in marine ecosystems where recruitment is unpredictable.
analysis.newsHeadline: First Come, First Served: Tiny Timing Differences Determine Winners in Coral Reef Fish Competition
analysis.essay:
I was watching two species of wrasse - Thalassoma hardwicke and T. quinquevittatum - duke it out on our experimental patch reefs in Moorea when I realized we might be seeing something important. These fish, settling at a standard length of 9-11 mm, were engaging in chases and fin bites over prime real estate on our coral patches. What struck me wasn't just that they were fighting, but when they were fighting - and how the timing of their arrival seemed to determine who won. Working with my colleague Adrian Stier, I began to suspect that in the chaotic world of coral reef recruitment, timing might be everything.

We wanted to answer a deceptively simple question: does it matter who shows up first? Reef fish communities experience repeated waves of colonization as larvae settle from the plankton in irregular pulses around the new moon. I'd observed that T. hardwicke and T. quinquevittatum settle asynchronously during these pulses, arriving at slightly different times. We constructed experimental patch reefs in Moorea, French Polynesia. Then we played puppet master with recruitment, capturing recent settlers and manipulating exactly when and in what order they arrived on our reefs.

The results were stark. Both species survived best in the absence of competitors, but when competitors were present, they did best when they arrived at the same time. Survival declined as each species entered the community progressively later than its competitor, and aggression by the early-arriving competitor increased correspondingly. The pattern held whether we were looking at competition between the two different species or just within T. hardwicke competing against itself. It wasn't about species identity - it was about timing.

What surprised me most was how consistent and strong these priority effects were. I'd expected some advantage to early arrival, but the magnitude caught me off guard. The mechanism behind this advantage remains unclear from our study - we don't know whether it's about size differences that develop over time, resource preemption, or simply the psychological advantage of being established. We also can't say exactly what resources they're competing for, though their similar habitat preferences and diets suggest overlap in what they need.

This matters because it suggests that competitive lotteries - essentially random winners determined by arrival order rather than inherent competitive ability - might be crucial for maintaining species diversity in marine systems. When recruitment is spatially and temporally unpredictable, as it is for most reef fishes, small differences in timing can flip competitive outcomes. This adds a layer of stochasticity to community assembly that traditional competition theory doesn't capture. It also means that factors affecting larval supply timing - like climate variability or oceanographic changes - could have cascading effects on adult community structure.

I'm left wondering about the broader implications. How common are these priority effects across different reef fish species? Do they scale up to affect entire community structure over multiple settlement events? And perhaps most intriguingly, are some species evolving to time their reproduction to take advantage of priority effects, breeding earlier to give their offspring a head start? The reefs around Moorea continue to pulse with new settlers each month, each arrival potentially reshuffling the competitive deck in ways we're only beginning to understand.

reviewDetails.overallAssessment: The article contains several fabricated details including specific measurements, numbers, and experimental procedures not found in the source paper. The main scientific findings are accurately represented, but the essay includes invented observational details and methodology specifics.
